newsitem.title: USA: HMOs in decline as investors fret about earnings.
newsitem.headline: HMOs in decline as investors fret about earnings.

text.p: Investors concerned about weak third quarter earnings sent the entire HMO sector into a tailspin on Tuesday.
The Morgan Stanley Healthcare Payor Index, weighted with HMO companies, fell five points, or over two percent, to 202.
"These are very volatile stocks with high price/earnings ratios, the whole HMO group. People are getting nervous," said Amy De Rham, Montgomery Securities analyst.
Oxford shares fell 2-7/8 to 41-1/2. The company is expected to post gains for the quarter when it reports earnings on November 5.
PacifiCare Health Systems Inc lost 2-15/16 to 68-5/16, FHP International Corp fell 1/2 to 35-1/4 and United Healthcare Corp dropped 107/8 to 36-5/8.
"There's just a lot of concern about third quarter earnings and so people are bailing," said one industry source.
Wall Street consensus earnings estimates are forecasting negative earnings comparisons for six of the 10 largest HMOs compared with last year's third quarter.
Analysts have also said expected pressure on profit margins throughout the HMO industry is not likely to lift in the near future.
